Posts.Content: Hi Marg.   Just a quick message hoping that the surgery went well and that you are comfortable. Sending big gentle hugs your way Amanda xx
Posts.Title: op day tomorrow

Posts.Content: Great news :)   Now rest up and let your body heal xx
Posts.Title: op day tomorrow

Posts.Content: Good luck today with your operation.  I had mine done two weeks ago.  My advise would be rest rest and rest some more.  The anesthetic will take a while to come out of your system.  Do your exercises and take all the help you can get.  Watch some films whilst laying on the sofa, daytime TV is still rubbish but it will occupy your mind.  Let us know how it goes.  Will be thinking of you :) Amanda xxx
Posts.Title: Op day at last...

Posts.Content: Lol Well done you.  Settle down with a book and just wait to be called to theatre.  Fingers crossed for you that it's all over quickly and you make a speedy recovery x
Posts.Title: Op day at last...

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed three weeks ago with breast cancer and have had some fabulous support from friends and family.  I hate to sound ungrateful, but the breast nurse that I have been assigned just does not feel right for me. I am 48 and have spent most of my life laughing, it's just the way I am, yet my breast nurse does not seem to have any kind of sense of humour. I know it is a serious matter having breast cancer, yet I feel that with my nurse I cannot be myself and I am holding back.  She will be with me for the next five years and I dont want to change who I am, or what I do yet I feel she is suppressing the real me.  Dont get me wrong, she is lovely and sweet, just not what I need.  Has anyone changed their breast nurse or do you know of how I can go about it? Thank you all.  Amanda xx
Posts.Title: Can I change my Macmillan breast nurse?

Posts.Content: I had my lumpectomy and some nodes removed 25th March.  Went back in 7th April to have node clearance as evidence of a spread.  Since then I have had problems with my scar healing and my boob going red, hot and swollen.  After numerous visits to the hospital, my own doctors, my nurse etc, the breast nurse discovered that the desolvable stitches had not desolved so she removed them. She seemed to think that this was the reason my scar was not healing. I was then put  on antibiotics (long term) for the redness in my lower boob.Neither my surgeon or my breast nurse seem particularly bothered about this, which I do find rather strange.  My surgeon also took me back into hospital 2 weeks ago to scrape out the wound and re-stitch the section of the scar that was not healing.   After my dressing came off I noticed that the surgeon had appeared to stitch 'above' the hole in one place instead of over the wound.  I mentioned this to him last week and he just shrugged and said, 'oh well, it's not looking any worse than before I stitched it!'.  He made me an appointment to see a radiotherapy consultant for this week.  Where he had 'scraped' the wound, it had begun to scab over so I was not too worried. Today my boob was sore when I woke up and I noticed that it had begun to swell again and the redness had started creeping up my boob.  I went to have a bath and looked in the mirror and I am gutted that the wound has opened up again :(   I cannot start my radiotherapy until the scar has healed and I feel really let down by my hospital and my surgeon.  Ive made an appointment with my GP for tomorrow to ask if I can be seen by a different hospital as I have lost all faith in the one I am under. Sorry to rant, I know others are much worse off than me but I just needed to get it off my chest Amanda
Posts.Title: Totally cheesed off

Posts.Content: Thank you Karen.  I thought the period between surgery and radiotherapy would be an easy ride, how wrong was I :) x
Posts.Title: Totally cheesed off

Posts.Content: After my lumpectomy and node removal on 25th March I found out last week that there was evidence of a spread to the lymph nodes so went back in on Tuesday to have the nodes removed from under my arm.  Woke up in a lot of pain but those lovely people in recovery kept giving me morphine to help.  Had the drain removed yesterday and was discharged from hospital as they were desperate for the bed. All of us who had breast surgery the day before were sent home (sign of the times I think in the NHS these days). Happy to be home, but did not feel that I was given enough information by the hospital on discharge.  I dont know if I am to keep the dressings on, if I can bath, if I have to continue to wear a bra 24hrs a day etc so will be ringing my BC nurse later.  On the plus side, my bed felt like the best place ever when I crawled into it last night.  Hope everyone has a happy day Amanda xx
Posts.Title: Second hurdle over :)

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone.  Had a visit from my GP today who has upped my painkillers to tramadol and liquid morphine.  She wasnt happy that  I was sent home from hospital so early and in so much pain.  But on the bright side, it's the weekend and the weather is supposed to be lovely so I shall be resting in the garden with a book and lots of cups of tea.  Hope you are all well and are recovering from your own surgeries :) Amanda xx
Posts.Title: Second hurdle over :)

Posts.Content: Thank you ladies.   I slept much better last night and have woken up in a cheery mood today.   Hope you all have a lovely, peaceful and restful day Much love Amanda xx
Posts.Title: Second hurdle over :)

Posts.Content: Thank you ladies.  i have spent the day in my pj's sleeping most of the day.  When Ive been awake Ive sat in the sunshine, ate rubbish and drank more cups of tea than I imagined possible. I spoke to my BC Nurse today and she has answered all my questions so I am feeling better now.  Tomorrow is a different day, and hopefully I will be feeling better :) Love and hugs to you all Amanda xx
Posts.Title: Second hurdle over :)

Posts.Content: Thanks Lorna xx Carla, I am  also a little concerned that it may have spread to the lymph nodes too, but my theory on this is I wont know till next Wednesday and I am not going to waste a week worrying about it.  I have far more important things to do like loving my children and appreciating all the support I am getting from friends and family.  This group is amazing.  I am so glad I stumbled across it.  I managed 7 hours sleep last night with the help of tramadol so I feel much better today.  Not so shaky or wobbly and just feel better in myself.  Its hard not being sucked into a false sense of security though about my fitness levels!  Anyway, if there is anything else I or anyone else can help you with, just ask.  The support here is great and there is normally someone around who will reply to you pretty quickly.  But as someone else has said, use your breast care nurse or your GP.  Please dont sit at home/work worrying about things.  Take care of yourself. Amanda xxx
Posts.Title: Start of treatment in 12 days...

Posts.Content: I had my surgery yesterday.  Feeling a bit sore today and extremely tired. Ive been advised not to work for at least 3 weeks (but I think it depends on your recovery and the job you do).  The best advice I was given today was to just listen to your body, rest when it needs it, exercise when you feel up to it, but take it one day at a time.  Best of luck to you.  Keep us updated on your progress :) Amanda x
Posts.Title: Start of treatment in 12 days...

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne. What a lovely post.  You are very inspirational.  I am having a down day, off to see the surgeon and oncologist later to get the results of my node clearance last week. Not looking forward to going, but after reading your post I will mutter under my breath 'I am a born survivor' constantly. Hope you have a truely wonderful day Much love Amanda xx
Posts.Title: A massive thank you to every one xxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne.   I was diagnosed with breast cancer on 3rd March and did feel exactly the same as you. I am slowly coming to terms with it now and am just about ready to start this journey to recovery.  As others say, have a cry if it will help, or have a giggle if that will help.  I am sure we all cope in different ways.  Best of luck to you.  Amanda xx
Posts.Title: It's starting to seem real ?

Posts.Content: Thank you Jennifer.  It helps so much talking to people who have gone through the same :) Good luck with your surgery next week.   Keep smiling Amandaxxxx
Posts.Title: I am so glad I found this group

Posts.Content: Just wanted to say how thankful that I am for stumbling across this page last week in my eternal search for answers. I read through these posts and know that everyone reading or replying is trying to help complete strangers come to terms with their diagnosis, helping them through their treatment or offering the hand of friendship for someone who is on the long road to recovery. Thanks everyone.  For someone who is petrified about her surgery next Tuesday, you have all helped me no end. Peace, love and laughs to you all Amanda xx
Posts.Title: I am so glad I found this group

Posts.Content: Thank you both.   I am having the WLE and Lymph nodes taken.  I was very fortunate to be included in a local trial for mammograms from the age of 47 and my breast cancer is early stages and there was no evidence of it spreading to my lymph nodes when they took the little sample at the same time as my biopsy. On Monday I go and have that radioactive (I think) injection into my boob and Surgery is scheduled for Tuesday morning and I am dreading it, along with not being able to wait as I know then that this horrid little lump will be out of me by Tuesday afternoon.  Fingers crossed it will then be a case of healing at home for a while then 3 and a half weeks of radiotherapy. Laughter has helped me though all the tough times in my life, and I have no intentions of changing that.  My sense of humour may be slightly warped at the moment but it lightens the dark times.  I am having more up days than down ones, so I am thankful for that. Amanda xxx
Posts.Title: I am so glad I found this group
